title: Profit-maximizing Cluster Hires

author: Behzad Golshan, Computer Science Department, Boston University

segmentation: Good afternoon everyone.

My name is Bess out Golshan from Boston University and I'm going to talk about profit maximizing clusters higher which is a joint work with orders Lappas from Stevens Institute of Technology and my advisor, Boston University.
So before I get into the details of the problem, I want to give you a basically high level description of what is it that we're looking into.
So if you look at the common job market, you see that it has two main components.
The first component are the jobs on the market.
And the other component are the workers.
So if you look at these components, you see that they.
Consists of different things.
So for example, for each job you have a set of skills which is required for completing that job.
And also it has a value that you gain once the job is completed.

Workers, on the other hand, they have some salary which if you hire them, you have to pay them that my salary and also they have a set of skills that they Masters and they can use them to do the jobs so clearly in this setting there is a matching problem you have to bring the workers do their jobs and create some values.
And that's what companies try to do.
They enter the market and they look for the right team and they want to do the right projects to make the most money right?
So these are different organizations or they can be project managers who just want to find the right team for the set of projects that they can do.
Or it can be even like a startups when some people try to team up together and basically find the right set of projects with the right set of people and accomplishment.
But the question that arises here.
Is that?
Who should be hired in which project should be done?
And this is the problem we're looking into.
So if you basically consider these settings, it's appears in men.
Places so for example what you see here.
There are.
These are like the major free websites for freelancers and exactly follows the same pattern.
So users common the website they post the profile of techniques or skills that they have.
They put a salary and also different people come onto the website and they basically posted jobs and they say how much you are willing to pay.
So the difference I think is slightly different from a common job.
Kid is basically if you consider the University, so there are different conferences and you know as school tries to have appearance in major conferences.

But there are different set of applicants who apply for the position in the in the University, and then you want to make sure that you have the right set of skills to be able to appear in these major conferences.
Alright, so back to our.
I think there are a few questions that we have to answer before we define our problem.
The first one is that are we going to pay the employer.
So for example, if I hire these two people that I show on the picture, they have a salary.
What I need to do is to basically pay them the salary and sum them up and pay them a salary so the cost is clear for creating the team.
The second question basically is that what you can do with the team that you form.
So.
Sorry, I just want to make sure that that alright.
So basically when you hire a team, you can go after any projects for which you have the writing skills.

So for example, if I hire those two people and I see that basically they know how to do Java, they know about node JS, then I can do the first project and also the second project because have the right set of skills.
So we call this the coverage of your team.
These are the projects they can do.
But the most important question is how do you make money right?
So we basically consider two different profit models and we basically a study.
The performance of our method under both models.
The first one is dollar based profit model.
Which basically means any project that you can cover.
You can go after you can apply for it, get the job and get the money.
Which is not too realistic because there are other peoples on the market who also apply for the same job.
So because of that we have a different model which is the competition based model.
So here so you can try to do different things to capture the competition.
What we did in this particular word is that we basically take the actual profit of the job and we divide it by the number of people who have the rarest skills.
So these are the other number of people who can also participate in that job because they have that rare skill.
Alright.
So now that we answered these questions, we are ready to define our problem.
The first problem that we've defined is called cluster hire and basically the question is that if you have a fixed budget.
Then which people you hire so that the cost of the team would be smaller than the budget and you also maximize the profit that you gain under any profit model we consider both.
So in the paper, we show that this problem is NP hard to solve and approximate within any factor.
And.
Because there is a close connection with the set cover problem, so you can read about that on the paper.

But this problem formulation is a little bit far from reality, because what happens is that workers are spread thin, meaning that you might ask a worker to do many jobs because simply because he had the right, the skills you say, OK, there are hundred jobs on the market that you can call that go and do all of them, which is not practical.
So we define a different version of the problem and we look more into that which we call T cluster hire.
So what it does is it basically limits the problem formulation a little bit further and says a worker can use his skill in at most he projects.
And usually pick a reasonable number 40 like two or three projects at the same time.
So in this case, the notion of coverage changes because your team can cover many projects, but you have to select which ones you want to do.
It turns out that this selection problem is also hard, but we can do a greedy approach to basically evaluate that.
Alright, now that I discuss about the problem and the complexity of the results, I'm going to present to you some of the algorithms that we have.
So the first algorithm that we studied is called expert greedy.
So what it does is that it basically.
Tries to pick the best expert at each iteration.

Adds it to the team that you already have right and the best expert is basically the expert that maximize that maximizes the profit to cost ratio, and you repeat this until the budget is completely consumed.
And if you look at that example, the power of this algorithm is using the skills that already your team has.
So for example, in this particular example you see job on the market that requires Java web design and graphic design.
What you already have Java.
Web design in your team.
These are the skills covered by your team, so you basically hire someone with graphic design and you can now complete that job, right?
So basically the expected he says I can pick Austin and I can earn that value, while if I go after different go after other workers I have to pay 10 but I still cannot complete any jobs.
So the top one is the one that expectedly chooses.
So the other Al Gore.
Item is called project greedy.
So project really tries to, you know differently, picks the best project at each iteration and try to do this until the budget is console.
So once you pick a project, you have to define the cost, how many workers you need to hire.
So project Greedy knows the skills that you already have, knows the skills that you need to be able to cover that project, and it tries to find the best team that basically can cover that.
So this is a set cover problem, weighted set cover problem, but you can do a greedy approach to find a good approximation of that, and that's what we do.
So the intuition here is that when you consider projects, you can basically, in other words, consider a combination of workers to be hired.
So for example, in this case this is the same example, but I basically increase the value of the second project, which expected doesn't pick.
Because expected, it looks like that and it says I have to pay for two workers to be able to get that and it cannot see, you know beforehand, it hires the first one and doesn't see any profit.

What project you can pick that project and see that you know yes, you need to hire two people, but once you hire those two people, you get a much more profit because you see the whole profit for the project.
So in that sense, project greedy has a better, you know.
Vision on the data and how it can be used.
So the last algorithm that we consider is click greedy.
So this is basically a speedup of project greedy.
And when we were looking at the data you can see that there are projects that are really related to each other.
So for example in this particular example you see that we have two projects.
The first one requires Java web design and SQL and the second one only requires Java and web design.
So if you look at the cost of each of covering each of these projects.
Based on the workers that I listed over there.
So for the first job you have to pay $30 for the second job you have.
Your cost is $20.
What you will see.
If you put these things together, the cost doesn't actually go up, so it seems very natural that you always go after these two projects together.
Because basically by combining them you get a much better profit to cost ratio.
So that's what we do.
We basically find these compatible projects and we get a click of these projects and we say, you know, they're all together.
By doing that, we basically reduces the number of candidates that our algorithm has to basically all go over and make sure that they are profitable or not.
Alright, so now I'm going to talk about the datasets that we use.
So we basically looked at two of the major freelancing websites.
We crawled the data from the experts and from the workers and we exactly have the information that you saw in the introduction.
Slide.
And in the paper we do a detailed analysis data analysis of these data.
So if you're interested to look at all aspects of the data, please read the paper.
But right now I'm just going to show you the distribution of the skills.
So the plot you see on the left is for Freelancer.
Which basically shows that most people try attend to basically list.
Many skills.
And this is basically the similar similarity of the workers, so this is the Jakarta similarity between their basically skills.
And you see that in Guru most basically workers are very similar to each other.
So with that I want to go to the experimental results and show you the experiments quickly.
So we only show the experiments.
Particulars are higher here because this is the more realistic setting.

You can find the experiments for the other one in the paper, and if you look at these plots, so basically the first row is for Guru, the second one for Freelancer, and then you see the dollar based column and the competition based color models.
The first thing that you notice is that project greedy is doing much better compared to expert greedy.
But on their competition based model there is a sudden drop.
Basically for the expert greedy.
And this is because when you get into the competition based model, the market becomes more competitive.
The experts are not.
You know, hiring an expert cannot do as much projects, so it's more simply look at the projects, the profitable projects, and pick them.
So the final point that I want to make here is that you will see that project greedy has a bigger drop, expert greedy has a bigger drop in Guru data set as opposed to the Freelancer data set.

And basically, if you compare this with the workers similarity, you will see that the reason is that in Group you have a lot of similar workers and that's the dense clusters you see in the middle, because they are all similar.
Greedy is confused which one to pick.
There is not much value in thinking similar experts.
So with that, I want to thank our supporters and also KDD for providing the travel awhile and which enabled me to give this talk and be here.
And I'd be happy to take any questions.
Thank you.
